articles.headline: House Panel Finds Conflicts in Executive Pay Consulting
articles.snippet: Conflicts of interest are pervasive among executive compensation consultants, according to a Congressional investigation.
articles.abstract: Conflicts of interest are pervasive among executive compensation consultants, according to a Congressional investigation.
articles.lead_paragraph: Conflicts of interest are pervasive among executive compensation consultants, according to a Congressional investigation. Moreover, the inquiry found, consultants who do other work for companies while helping them devise executive pay recommended significantly higher pay packages than consultants who had no such additional relationships.

articles.headline: Pushed Out of Baghdad, Insurgents Move North
articles.snippet: A growing number of Sunni insurgents have relocated to Mosul and other places in northern Iraq.
articles.abstract: A growing number of Sunni insurgents have relocated to Mosul and other places in northern Iraq.
articles.lead_paragraph: MOSUL, Iraq, Dec. 5  Sunni insurgents pushed out of Baghdad and Anbar Provinces have migrated to this northern Iraqi city and have been trying to turn it into a major hub for their operations, according to American commanders.

articles.headline: Gunman at an Omaha Mall Kills 8 and Himself
articles.snippet: A gunman in camouflage and wielding a rifle opened fire in a mall crowded with holiday shoppers.
articles.abstract: A gunman in camouflage and wielding a rifle opened fire in a mall crowded with holiday shoppers.
articles.lead_paragraph: OMAHA, Dec. 5  A gunman in camouflage and wielding a rifle opened fire on Wednesday in a department store at a mall here crowded with holiday shoppers, killing eight people and wounding five others, before turning the gun on himself.
articles.byline: By Ardy Friedberg and Monica Davey

articles.headline: Pulpit Was the Springboard for Huckabee’s Rise
articles.snippet: Mike Huckabee’s 2008 campaign has been shaped by his two decades as an evangelical pastor and broadcaster.
articles.abstract: Mike Huckabee’s 2008 campaign has been shaped by his two decades as an evangelical pastor and broadcaster.
articles.lead_paragraph: In August 1980, as the conservative Christian movement was first transforming American politics, Ronald Reagan stood before a Dallas stadium full of 15,000 foot-stomping, hand-clapping evangelicals and pledged his fealty to the Bible. “All the complex and horrendous questions confronting us at home and worldwide have their answer in that single book,” said Mr. Reagan, the Republican presidential nominee.
articles.byline: By Jodi Kantor and David D. Kirkpatrick

articles.headline: Wary of Risk, Bankers Sold Shaky Mortgage Debt
articles.snippet: Wall Street firms are coming under scrutiny for their role in selling risky mortgage-related securities to investors.
articles.abstract: Wall Street firms are coming under scrutiny for their role in selling risky mortgage-related securities to investors.
articles.lead_paragraph: As the subprime loan crisis deepens, Wall Street firms are increasingly coming under scrutiny for their role in selling risky mortgage-related securities to investors.
articles.byline: By Jenny Anderson and Vikas Bajaj

articles.headline: Bristol-Myers to Eliminate 4,800 Jobs
articles.snippet: Besides layoffs, the company said it would sell or close half its 27 manufacturing plants worldwide, farm out some manufacturing and winnow its portfolio of products.
articles.abstract: Besides layoffs, the company said it would sell or close half its 27 manufacturing plants worldwide, farm out some manufacturing and winnow its portfolio of products.
articles.lead_paragraph: Bristol-Myers Squibb said yesterday that it would cut approximately 10 percent of its work force of 43,000 employees, continuing a year of pharmaceutical industry layoffs as drug makers adapt to a more competitive environment.

articles.headline: Meat Processors Look for Ways to Keep Ground Beef Safe
articles.snippet: Even as the beef industry spends hundreds of millions of dollars a year to keep harmful pathogens out of the meat it sells to the public, it appears to be losing ground.
articles.abstract: Even as the beef industry spends hundreds of millions of dollars a year to keep harmful pathogens out of the meat it sells to the public, it appears to be losing ground.
articles.lead_paragraph: LEXINGTON, Neb.  In the last decade, Tyson Fresh Meats has transformed its slaughterhouse here to combat a potentially deadly type of food poisoning, adding huge chambers to scald carcasses and wash them in acid, steam vacuums to suck away microbes and elaborate gear to test hundreds of meat samples a day.

articles.headline: Tracing Business Acumen to Dyslexia
articles.snippet: A study concluded that dyslexics were more likely than nondyslexics to excel in oral communication and problem solving and to own two or more businesses.
articles.abstract: A study concluded that dyslexics were more likely than nondyslexics to excel in oral communication and problem solving and to own two or more businesses.
articles.lead_paragraph: It has long been known that dyslexics are drawn to running their own businesses, where they can get around their weaknesses in reading and writing and play on their strengths. But a new study of entrepreneurs in the United States suggests that dyslexia is much more common among small-business owners than even the experts had thought.

articles.headline: Details in Military Notes Led to Shift on Iran, U.S. Says
articles.snippet: American intelligence agencies obtained notes last summer from deliberations of Iranian military officials involved in the nuclear weapons program.
articles.abstract: American intelligence agencies obtained notes last summer from deliberations of Iranian military officials involved in the nuclear weapons program.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Dec. 5  American intelligence agencies reversed their view about the status of Iran’s nuclear weapons program after they obtained notes last summer from the deliberations of Iranian military officials involved in the weapons development program, senior intelligence and government officials said on Wednesday.
articles.byline: By David E. Sanger and Steven Lee Myers

articles.headline: OPEC Finds Price Range to Live With
articles.snippet: After a one-day meeting in Abu Dhabi, OPEC cemented the impression that it wanted to keep oil prices at levels that would have been unthinkable a few years ago, leaving its output goal unchanged.
articles.abstract: After a one-day meeting in Abu Dhabi, OPEC cemented the impression that it wanted to keep oil prices at levels that would have been unthinkable a few years ago, leaving its output goal unchanged.
articles.lead_paragraph: When oil prices were approaching the milestone of $100 a barrel a few weeks ago, OPEC, the global oil cartel, expanded production and sought to jawbone prices down. In January, when prices were near $50 and falling, OPEC cut supplies to stem the decline.

articles.headline: Looking Beyond Megapixels
articles.snippet: For the holidays, a summary of digital cameras, all priced below $300.
articles.abstract: For the holidays, a summary of digital cameras, all priced below $300.
articles.lead_paragraph: You may have your holiday traditions: caroling, stockings, candles, whatever. But here at The New York Times Institute of Gadgetology, we have a tradition of our own. Every December since 2001, we’ve asked: “How much digital camera can you get for $300?”
